bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, January 18, 1901

div1.p: Sternberg orders Reed to proceed to Washington, D.C. from Havana, Cuba, in order to continue his investigation into yellow fever at the Army Medical Museum in Washington, D.C. The letter and order are dated January 17 and January 18, 1901. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, January 17, 1901.
To the
ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE ARMY.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to recommend that Major Walter Reed, Surgeon,
U.S. Army, be ordered to proceed from Columbia Barracks, Cuba, to
this city, upon the adjournment of the Pan-American Medical Congress,
Havana, Cuba, to which he is a delegate by virtue of paragraph 21,
S.O. 302, A.G.O., December 27, 1900, for the purpose of continuing,
in the laboratory of the Army Medical Museum, this city, his investi-
gation with reference to the cause and prevention of yellow fever.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, G.M. Sternberg Surgeon General, U.S. Army.
TO BE RETAINED WITH PAPERS
SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 15. }
HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, January 18, 1901.
Extract.
* * * * * * *
18. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, will upon the adjournment of the
Pan-American Medical Congress at Havana, Cuba, proceed to
Washington, District of Columbia, and report in person to the
Surgeon General of the Army for the purpose of continuing
his investigation at the Army Medical Museum in this city
with reference to the cause and prevention of yellow fever.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
* * * * * * *
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:
H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
